nodes.text: A simple dynamic OLS/GLS estimator framework can produce efficient estimators of cointegrating vectors in systems with deterministic components and variables of differing higher orders of integration, and these estimators can be used to study long-run empirical relations such as U.S. Ml money demand

Method: Construct dynamic OLS (DOLS) and dynamic GLS (DGLS) estimators by regressing integrated variables on contemporaneous levels, leads and lags of first differences and constants, motivated as Gaussian MLEs for a two-sided triangular representation

Claim: Under general I(d) conditions and mild assumptions (finite parameterization or truncation of two-sided filters), DOLS and DGLS are asymptotically efficient, produce Wald statistics with chi-squared limits, and their unconditional distributions are mixed normal

Method/Evidence: Extend triangular representation to general I(d) systems, orthogonalize errors via two-sided filters D(L), transform regressors to canonical form zt = Bxt, and derive asymptotic limits using block scaling and Brownian motion functionals

Result: Theorems showing (i) scaled DGLS has mixed normal limit, (ii) scaled DOLS has mixed normal limit and DOLS and DGLS are asymptotically equivalent for the integrated-coefficient block, (iii) Wald tests for restrictions on cointegrating vectors are asymptotically chi-squared
Method: Monte Carlo experiments comparing SOLS, DOLS (two covariance methods), DGLS, PBSR (spectral), PHFM (fully modified), and Johansen VECM MLE across designs approximating money-demand dynamics

Evidence (Monte Carlo): DOLS and DGLS eliminate bias present in static OLS in many designs; all estimators perform well with simple short-run dynamics but performance diverges in designs mimicking U.S. money, income, and interest-rate dynamics; DOLS often has lowest RMSE in difficult designs

Limitation/Evidence: For realistic designs with strong serial correlation and long memory (infinite-order d(L)), truncation of leads/lags induces finite-sample bias for DOLS/DGLS; asymptotic approximations understate sampling variability for small/medium samples
Application: Use DOLS, DGLS and other estimators to estimate long-run U.S. Ml money demand (1900-1989) with variables m, p, y, and short-term interest rate r (various specifications I(1)/I(2))

Result (empirical): Over 1900-1989 the long-run Ml demand relation is empirically plausible and stable; DOLS full-sample 95% confidence intervals are income elasticity in (0.88,1.06) and interest semielasticity in (-0.127,-0.075)

Result (empirical nuance): Estimates based on postwar data alone (1946 onward) are unstable and imprecise because postwar series are dominated by a single low-frequency trend (income and interest rise while real balances are flat), producing large sampling uncertainty and high negative correlation between estimated income and interest elasticities

Evidence/Diagnostics: Formal tests (DOLS-based break tests, ADF on residuals, likelihood surfaces for Johansen MLE) fail to reject a stable cointegrating relation across 1900-1989; Monte Carlo shows asymptotic chi-squared approximations can badly understate coverage in small postwar samples

Conclusion: Combined theoretical and empirical evidence supports a single stable long-run U.S. Ml demand over 1900-1989 with income elasticity near one and interest semielasticity near -0.10, but precise estimation requires long spans of data and careful finite-sample treatment

Recommendation/Claim: Use multiple asymptotically efficient estimators (DOLS, DGLS, Johansen, spectral/fully-modified) and long samples; prefer DOLS in many empirical scenarios because of favorable finite-sample behavior, but be cautious about pretesting and truncation bias
